column5: Households Served by Municipal Recycling Program
column16: Weeks the drop-off center open to residents
column17: Municipal Buildings Trash and Recycling Service
column21: Solid Waste program funded by property tax?
column22: Solid Waste program funded by annual fee?
column23: Solid Waste program funded by per-visit fee?
column24: Solid Waste program funded by PAYT revenue?
column39: Private Hauler regulations that require recycling
column41: Reuse area at transfer station / recycling center?
column44: Does trash disposal tonnage include bulky waste?
column82: Did your municipality host comprehensive household hazardous waste collection events in 2015?
column86: Comments/Additional Information

Our municipal trash and recycling program includes pickup for 713 grandfathered single family condominium units.The link for the Bulky Item Price List can be found on the Town of Abington website abingtonma.gov, at the Health Department Section under News and Announcements.

Amesbury has the haulers collect trash and recycling in the central business district only. (380 units) Trash is collected twice a week. (T, F) and recycling once a week (F)There are a few condo complexes that do receive trash and recycling collection from the municipal contract. (5 for trash and 6 for recycling)Amesbury provides a curbside white goods collection once a month. (52 items this year)E-Waste is collected by a local company and quantities are from two events sponsored by the Lions Club and advertised through City website, City Flyers, etc.
All hard to handle bulky / commercial items residents have to deliver to the main transfer station in Edgartown 52 weeks per year items are excepted.

Items indicated as collected year round are collected on the alternate (every other) Saturday schedule of the Ashby Recycle Center & Transfer Station. Note this is a change from the 2nd & 4th Saturday schedule reported in the CY2014 report. The alternate Saturday schedule was introduced for FY2016. There is no tonnage for rigid plastics, as we didn't have them hauled in CY2015.

We also service private commercial haulers that provide curbside recycling and trash pickup to local residents and non-Athol residents in neighboring communities. The private haulers account for an additional 1523.12 tons of trash collected. This amount is in addition to the tonnage reported in Question 5. The tons reported on Question 5 are the amounts collected in the PAYT bags.
I am waiting for ewaste, scrap metal and yard waste figures.
Household Hazardous Waste Day and Spring Cleanup are held alternating years. Other materials are collected for recycling at each event. We also refer residents to NEDT in Sutton.
Bulky items are paid with purchased stickers issued in $5 increments. Stickers are applied to items based on a fee schedule posted in various locations and the town website.

We collected 7.1 tons of residential C&D at Oct. 3 Collection Event and 37 tons of C&D that was "dumped" at the DPW yard. Scrap Metal includes - 53.89 tons (1.83 at May 30 event from residents, remainder from DPW facilities). Batteries 1.51 tons (from residents and Bedford facilities). Tires .95 tons (residents, DPW).
Our compost site (drop off for residents) opened approximately 4 weeks late in 2015 due to late and heavy snow cover.

Apartments/Condos services are all eligible (non-40B) excluding complexes that choose not to be a part of program. Not determined by # units.Drop off for yard waste (5 weeks) is only for Christmas Trees. No other yard waste may be dropped off.We get quantities for white goods and E-waste in # units combined. All tonnages are estimated (40% E waste at 50# EA, 60% white goods at 175# EA).Latex paint accepted in regular trash as long as hard. Oil based paint accepted only at HHW event.
Households with senior citizens receive 40 free 30 gallon stickers per year. These are the only residents who receive this PAYT benefit

We transitioned our baling facility to become a regional single stream recyclables transfer facility. As a result we have been taking in commercial single stream recyclables as well as tonnage from Falmouth. See other notes as written in 2014.
Our tipping fee was $74 per ton from Jan. 2015 thru June 2015. The rest of the year was $60.60

Our drop off for composting grass, leaves, brush is in our contiguous neighboring Town of Topsfield.We do receive income from collecting books: 3 tons @ $67/ton for total of $200.00Our costs for curbside recycling is included in the total trash and recycling contract for collection,hauling and recycling with JRM. The recycling costs are not broken out separately.
Boylston is part of the Wachusett Earth Day Recycling Center.
Book collection was added recently to Recycling Center. In April, Braintree will add rigid plastics via drop-off, year round at Recycling Center.

Medical waste/sharps are encouraged to be brought to F.D. for recycling. We encourage oil based / latex paints to be brought to HW events. We have paint shed for recycling. All recyclable batteries go through our Barnstable county Program. We have magazine / book swap rack for public before being recycled. Book and clothing bins at our Swap Shop as well as T.S. We do not have food waste program as of yet but are researching thru Recycling Commission for Schools and possibly T.S. A fee schedule is on the towns website. Town of Brewster.gov

Paint Swap and Paint Collection offered April 1 through October 31, six days per week. 6-Family homes and above not eligible for municipal trash pickup but may use Recycle Center free of charge. Trash program - First 32 gallon barrel/unit/week included in fee. Additional trash must be in PAYT Bags. Trash fee also includes unlimited recycling and yard waste as well as 1 large item and 1 tv or appliance per week.

33% of residential buildings with 9 units and above receive trash collection with a private hauler. 4% of residential buildings with 9 units and above receive recycling collection with a private hauler.Food scrap tonnage includes from the city's curbside residential pilot, 4 drop-off sites, schools/city buildings, Soilcycle/Bootstrap customers in Cambridge, & lbs diverted through home composting.

The Town of Charlton utilizes a drop-off center partnered with Southbridge Recycling and Disposal Park in Southbridge MA which is open to Charlton residents. The number of households that use the drop off are not tracked. The Town does not offer resident trash/recycling program and residents contract with their own hauler of their choice, but they still can use the drop-off center. There is no cost to the Town to use the drop-off center. There is no fee charged for the drop-off of (2) bags of waste, unlimited acceptable recyclables, and one bulk item per week. Residents may be charged a reasonable drop-off fee for additional bulk items.
Municipal single stream curbside recycle collection program began on 7/15/15.

The Town of Dartmouth does contract with a private contractor to pick up solid waste in some municipal buildings. Recycling picked up is done by the town. Street sweepings (1,614.62 tons) this is not counted as solid waste because the district reuses this material for cover.

Twice a year the Sustainability Advisory Committee hosts a Styrofoam, metal, electronics, textiles collection day. The events are held in the spring and the fall. The fall event coincides with HHW Day run by the Board of Health at the DPW. In 2015 we held a third Styrofoam collection event after Christmas, but found that either it was too close to the holiday, being the Saturday after Christmas or that most packaging is now not in the form of Styrofoam, but rather plastic. The Spring and Fall events are better attended, so we will not be holding the December event in the future.
4. One pre-school participates in program; the high school does not.8. Cardboard includes mixed paper8. Bulky rigid plastics are included in container collection
The number of households served in the municipal trash and recycling programs includes condominium complexes of varying sizes that choose to participate in the municipal program.
Two HHHW events for Eastham Residents - one in Eastham , one in Orleans
Mattresses, carpets are a part of wood as we collect them collectively as C&D
http://www.framinghamma.gov/173/Bulky-Item-Disposal

Trash and recycling numbers include totals from Transfer Station, so trash tonnage may be higher than past years. Our bulky waste program is by the piece, we do not weigh the items. Our paint collection is not truly year round, the paint shed closes in November and reopens in April. In additon to Sharps collection, we have 2 medication waste collection boxes in the community. Our shrps and medication waste is part of a regional effort involving 12 member communities in a public health district.

The cost is $2.50 per 30 gallon bag, with punch casts costing $75.00 each. Generally, to dump waste at our transfer station one must purchase a punch card to do so. Any town resident or business can use the transfer station to dispose of the recycling items as long as they show proof of residency. We do not sell or provide transfer station stickers. The PAYT program collects enough money to cover our costs, but we appropriate in our budget the amount we believe will collect in PAYT payments instead of setting up a revolving fund. This year we checked the "property tax" box because our appropriation included budget appropriation and free cash to purchase a new compactor as well funds tor new controls as well as new decking and bringing transfer station up to code compliance.Our transfer station attendant monitors and enforces the mandatory recycling requirement at the transfer station. Local private haulers are responsible for enforcing the mandatory recycling for their customers.While town residents did not have access to a comprehensive household hazardous waste collection "event" in another community in 2015, the town did contract with NEDT to allow residents of Granville to utilize the NEDT Household Hazardous Products Collection Center in neighboring Westfield. The Town set up the program to allow residents the opportunity to dispose of a comprehensive list of hazardous products not accepted at the Transfer Station. To incentivize the program the Town pays the first $30 of residents' costs for disposal. Program is advertised at the Transfer Station, on the Town website and in the local monthly newsletter.
We accept HHW year round for our residents.
We have combined many of our Waste Ban recyclable items under the wood catagory

*Trash and Recycling Collection - The City collects condominium complexes but do not exactly reflect criteria of "Section 1". City currently collects 2,041 total condo units that range from duplexes to large complexes. This figure is included in the number of households served. *Yard Waste - Leaves cost $175-200 per 100 cubic yards. Annual Leaf collection day material was delivered to vendor for $75 per 32 yard load (22 loads) - Total cost for leaves and grass disposal for 2015 = $10,900. Brush does not incur costs. Brush is chipped and hauled away in 100 yard loads (22 loads in 2015 - 2,200 yards of wood chips) Lower tonnage than actual amount brought in as vendor did not take all grass and leaves before CY end. (an additional 700-800 yards remained at years end).*Tires - Recycled 9.29 tons of scrap tires.

The TOwn of Holden pays a fixed monthly bill to casella which includes trash and recycling pick-up and the disposal of 150 tons of recycling, if they go over this tonnage on a per monthly basis, they get a "recycling bonus" for $64 per ton (our tipping fee)

Residents are allowed to put out ONE 35-gallon barrel for free each week. Additional trash must be in overthrow bags or is left behind.Ipswich pays $350 per month, not per ton, to dispose of our yard waste from our dropoff facility.Ipswich has a private-pay curbside composting pilot program. Residents pay $1 per week and the DPW pays 10 cents per household per week. The approximate total cost for 2015 (given the fluctuating rate of participation) to the DPW was $8,100.Our trash household numbers and recycling household numbers are different because Ipswich collects recycling from businesses and residences not served by trash pickup. Our downtown is very dense and businesses are allowed to put out their weekly recycling for collection by our hauler. We also offer recycling dropoff at our transfer station to condos and apartments not served curbside. We also offer curbside pickup to multi-family residences (more than four units) that were "grandfathered in" before the new trash policy was adopted.

Note: Textiles/Used Clothing are collected in numerous containers at the transfer station and donated (i.e. Red Cross, etc.). The clean wood program just recently was implemented a couple of months ago. Lakeville had been holding off on implementation until a local receiver of the material began to take it (ABC). There have not been any clean wood deliveries yet for data. The mattress program was just implemented in December 2015 after receiving grant funds for a mattress container. As of 1/14/2016, a delivery of the mattresses has not been made for data purposes.
Lee does not have a municipal program for trash and recycling.

For recycling we did not pay or receive revenue. Instead IPR hauled for free and received any revenue generated.Bulky plastic and mattress' currently go in the trash. We sponsor hazardous waste days 8 times a year.

The Town of Lunenburg is a member of the Devens HHW which collects many of the other recycled material not collected at the curb. The town is next to the Town of Townsend and has access to their drop off center which is open twice a month. The town is also a member of Nashoba Boards of Health which collects sharps year round.

Hazardous Products Collection sponsored by CMW District. Scrap Metal/White Goods, C&D Materials, Swap Shop or Book Re-Use by CMW District #8 (other recycled material) scrap metal/white goods and e-waste - CMW District. Medical Waste/Sharps-Board of Health. Recycling Tonnage - cardboard, steel/tin cans, glass, plastic, newspaper - included in single stream. Bulky waste is accepted at the CMWRRDD Transfer Station. They would be responsible for tracking the tonnage collected.

Please be advised that I have listed textiles, bulky rigid plastics, book/media and consider the carpet recycling program as 1 or 2 times per year for 2015 given the construction/completion of the new Resident Drop-off Facility (RDF). Please note all containers have been placed at the facility and residents are taken advantage of the new programs and seem quite pleased.With respect to revenue at the RDF any and all revenue generated from recyclables from the Resident Drop-off Facility goes to WeCare Environmental per the city's contract agreement with WeCare Environmental.

Collection of frequency; there isn't any column that says OTHER. We collect oil, oil filters and oil based paint/stain from May 1 -October 31Other recycled material; during the year prices changed in scrap metal and collection of CRT's CRT's tonnage was 21 tons; we paid .15 cents per ton for CRT's when entering the figure it isn't correct.I am leaving those blank because unable to make it come out correct.

In the Scrap Metal rate per ton field we used an average as the price varies depending on the type of metal (light iron, cast iron, mixed steel, etc.). In the Rigid Plastic Cost per ton field I put zero as there is no cost per ton, but there is a cost per haul, and we had no clear way to include that. In the apartments/condos we service, we offer service, but many choose to use a private hauler. In the question about charging for bulk waste, we do not charge curbside, only when brought into the recycle center.

The town changed to a automated trash and recycling service in July 2015. The town is now utilizing 64 gallon trash carts and 96 gallon recycling carts offering single stream recycling on a bi-weekly basis and trash service on a weekly basis. We have seen a tremendous drop in our trash tonnage as well as an increase in our recycling tonnage. In addition, our contract with SEMASS ended December 2015. We are now delivering trash to the Middleborough Landfill which is being operated by Waste Management. Our contract which expires in June 2031 allows us 6000 free tons of trash disposal, any tonnage above 6000 ton is charge at a rate of $25.00 per ton up to 10,000 ton. The town does not receive any revenue from Waste Management for the single stream recycling collected curbside or dropped off at the landfill.
Mattresses/Boxspring, Computer and Electronics, Carpet, Upholstered Furniture, and White Goods - $15.00 each - town charges $21.00
Monroe joined NBSWMD in September of 2015.
Montague collects yard waste and brush year-round but does not have weights or volumes.

Mattress- We are charged $35. per mattress. Above chart does not seem to reflect our totals. Numbers are for 1/2 year We were not charged first halfTextiles/used clothing - We contract company to provide dumpster- no cost to town we do not get weight summaryRecycle Electronics - we pay by container - 24 yd @ $925.x 6 pickups =$5550
PAYT bag costs listed in survey are for bags sold in packages of 10- not the cost for individual bags.

The single stream automated cart program began on June 23, 2014.Single unit buildings received 65-gallon carts, multiple unit buildings received 95-gallon carts.Other Recycled Materials:Antifreeze = .88 tonsBatteries = 1.56 tonsBooks = 16.04 tonsBulky items that are recycled = 910.73 tonsConstruction and demolition = 189.95 tonsCooking oil = 1.52 tonsMercury items = 3.11 tonsMotor oil = 4.69Shredded paper = 7.85 tonsStyrofoam = .39 tonsTires = 9.75 tonsAlso composted food waste at Connecting for Change, a youth wellness day, and a Thanksgiving church dinner.
We now have 2 days per week for drop off recycling and one Saturday per month for drop off recycling.

Our recycling is not only encouraged but mandate for Non profits if they wish to participate in Curbside pickups. In addition we do collect hazardous waste including chemicals, acids, bases, oxidizers and photography chemicals.

Under Section 2 (Municipal Trash Program) I selected "none" for the multifamily /apartments for our trash and recycling programs, but individual households in those dwelling may participate in the municipal program with the purchase of a transfer station sticker.Under Section 7 (Program Elements), small businesses are allowed to participate in the municipal program, but we have not actively promoted the program this year (if that is what is meant by encouragement).Under Section 8 (Other Recycled Materials) the DPW has not yet calculated yard waste totals for CY 2015. I have used last year's number.Also under Section 8: (Basic Recycled Materials), statistics from the Springfield MRF for the period July-December 2015, are not yet available. I have doubled the figures from the first half of 2015.

1) There is a private hauler in licensed to collect trash and recycling in Northborough with approximately 962 customers, but their customers can also use Town bags if they choose to. 2) The Town only holds one HHWD event per year as a result of a severe drop in participation once a $10 per box fee was implemented in 2005. 3) The trash and recycling reported above does not include school amounts because the School Department hired a separate contractor to collect trash and recycling as of July 1, 2011. 4) The amount of yard waste disposed of in 2015 was less than the previous year as the DPW had cleaned out an area which accumulated yard waste over several years. 5) The Town offered all condominiums the opportunity to join the PAYT program when it started in 2003 but only some have joined.

Medical waste as in old prescriptions are collected at the Oak Bluffs Police Station whenever they are open and front door is unlockedSharps are collected at Martha's Vineyard Hospital Lab anytime they are open
Some rigid plastics are included in containers.

The Town of Plainfield does not have a website. Community events are shared through a local town newsletter and posted throughout the community - Town Offices, churches, post office, businesses, and the Transfer Station. Information concerning Transfer Station Fees and Household Hazardous Waste Collection events are additionally hosted on the HRMC website for the Town. Recycling news articles are frequently posted in the Town newsletter by the town's HRMC representative.

Recycling - out of 3656 households in Plainville, 1864 are on the municipal collection program, it is therefore assumed that 1792 have private collection. Out of the 1792 that have private collection, it has been confirmed that 814 multi family units have recycling service. Either recycling carts or recycling only dumpsters are located on the multi unit properties.
Curbside Service is not available to Apartment or Condominium complexes with more than 4 residences. The only available option for these locations is drop-off.

Drop off services available year round to town residents for recycled materials, other recycled materials, CHARM and bulky waste at the Wachusett Watershed Regional Recycling Center. HHW collections are located at the Wachusett Watershed Regional Recycling Center for all households and are supported, in part, by the town.
This is the first year that we are collecting mattresses. So far it is a successful program.
We appreciate any assistance number calculations regarding e-waste and yardwaste
We are private subscription Community
Many of the collection itemized above are not properly being tracked, this is part of the reason we are needing assistance.

If a household already has a Transfer Station sticker they are allowed one Bulky Waste coupon free of charge. If a household does not have a Transfer Station Sticker they are charged $25.00 for a Bulky Waste coupon.For our mixed recycling and cardboard recycling we are charged a flat rate per load. That rate is $243.80 per load. For 2015 there were 28 loads of mixed recycling and 27 loads of cardboard.

We have also started to collect porcelain toilets and sinks for delivery to Conigliaro. We had one shipment of 40 units in December costing $600.We also allow the Lions Club to collect redeemable bottles and cans. They collect an enormous amount, but I haven't asked them to quantify it in a number of years.
We are a member of the Deven's Hazardous Waste

Properly hardened/dried latex paint accepted all year. Liquid latex not accepted at any time. Oil based paints only accepted during Household Hazardous Waste Collection events.A joint Household Hazardous Waste Collection event happened October 31, 2015 in conjunction with Easthampton, MA and was open to all residents of the two Towns by appointment+.
Section 4b. I checked annual fee, but our costs for disposal are reimbursed by Casella/SRD through our contract.

There are privately-owned household hazardous waste collection facilities in near-by municipalities (closest in Westfield - one Town over) in which residents can dispose of household hazardous waste all year long. Town residents have commented how more convenient this is compared to a once-a-year event.
Spencer & N. Brookfield co-host an annual HHHW collection day usually in the fall at N. Brookfield's Paint/HazMat Center.
Recycling Coordinator position has not been funded since September 4, 2015.
NEDT has a Sutton office and takes walk in customers

school / municipal paper/cardboard tonnage from paper only dumpsters is not included in curbside recycle totals.Residents have access to free rigid plastic drop-off year round at out secondary fiber purchaser located in neighboring Salem.Swampscott/Marblehead share two HHWD at equal expense in Marblehead each year.

For trash and recycle households served, some of the condos and apartments in the five to six unit range, seven to eight unit range, and nine and above range are collected as part of the municipal program, but not all.

we have a $5.00 access ticket or a $45.00 vehicle sticker cost for the dropping off of yard waste. Our 2 Elementary Schools did a pilot program of composting food waste, but tonnage was not calculated for the pilot program.
Household Hazardous Waste collection takes place in more than one community throughout the year.

Waltham collects recycling from most condo and apartment buildings, but not all. Some of these complexes were built without the prospect of obtaining solid waste collection services from the City.Waltham collects recycling from businesses who apply and are located on existing recycling collection routes. A total of 600 businesses will be accepted.The City's Compost Bin Program relies on Lexington; Lexington permits Waltham residents to purchase compost bins on state contract at their Public Works Department..Although we collect selected rigid plastics in the curbside collection, the tonnage is not calculated separately.
Wareham contracts with a private disposal company for municipal buildings. It offers a sticker system (Optional) for solid waste and a free mdrop off center for recyclables.

Regarding Other Recycled Materials Category: - Textiles/Used Clothing are collected at School as well as Transfer Station. T.S. total is 2450lbs, Town-wide total is 21,760lbs - Yard Waste is collected and ground for mulch which is used throughout Town by the DPW and available for residents to take. - Electronics & E-Waste are collected once a month for recycling and tracked per-item (430 Items in CY2015)

The Wendell Transfer Station accepts scrap metal and appliances but a company takes the metal items at no cost so there are no weights. The Town's website indicates that scrap metal and appliances are accepted at the transfer station: http://www.wendellmass.us/index.php/governance/services/wrats.html

Bulky plastic items were asked to be brought to a dedicated dumpster at our 2015 earth day fair event but only a few pieces were brought so there is no tonnage entered.Leaf and yard waste tonnage does NOT include drop off by residents which is NOT in the above total but estimated at 800 tons.We collected Food waste at one school - Tatham ElementaryBulky Waste -a total of 207 tons** of bulky waste was collected in two ways; 1. from curbside pickup by the Towns Contactor K&W that had a scaled weight of = 150 tons**; 2. an estimated 57 tons** (generally 100 pounds estimated per load x 1,140 loads dropped off by Residents) at the Town's Transfer Station operated by K&W

yard waste (brush, not l eaves) i s accepted at a drop­off facility on 2 collection dates during 2015. The Fire Dept picks up Christmas trees one weekend after Christmas. Residents pay a fee. This i s coordinated completely by the Fire Dept .Household Hazardous Waste collections are held every other year - even years. We inform residents that Lexington has events once per month that they may at tend on a fee basis.

HHW Collection in another community is a business "NEDT" located in Sutton, MA (NEDT.org). They are open year round 2 days a week and by appointment and some Saturdays in the summer for Massachusetts, RI & CT residents. Our metal, glass and plastic are collected separately. We are currently recycling plastic with a return of $0. The glass is a cost to the municipality at $25/ton. The metal is paid as follows: light iron at $45/GT, tin cans at $40/GT, aluminum at .37/LB. Christmas trees are collected only during the month of January. We have not received the collection amount for the textile from Bay State and the other vendor, which is the Salvation Army, does not track the amount collected so we are not able to provide any information on the textile/clothing collection for 2015 at this time.
HHW reciprocal events twice a year at: Abington, Cohasset, Hanover, Hingham, Kingston, Norwell, Rockland, Whitman, Plymouth, Duxbury, Hanson, Middleborough.

Residents can use the Minuteman Hazardous Waste Facility in Lexington on a pay per use basis. They could also use Clean Harbors in Braintree, MA on a pay per use basis on Saturdays from April to November.

Item #2 - Curbside Recycling is a available to residents in household units of 6 or less. Drop-Off recycling is available to all household units.Item 6 - Yard Waste curbside is only during Fall Leaf Collection and April through November/December we operate three drop-off sites.#8 The conversion factor for cu. yds. of yard waste appears to be much lower than what has been used in the past and even in the DEP's own Volume to Weight Conversions for Recyclable Material.

Anyone in Yarmouth may utilize the various recycling services offered at the Yarmouth Disposal Area. Our swap shop is currently closed due to volunteers violating building codes. Please note that we do not pay to recycle all E-wastes, reported in section 8. CRT's are the only items paid for.
